spots.label: Home
spots.notes: This was definitely one of the best apartments I've stayed in while in Europe and most certainly the best I've rented in Milan. 10th floor - panoramic city view. Worth the money.

spots.label: Bottega del Vino
spots.notes: This is a wine shop with picnic tables where you can sit and have a free snack (or paid ones) and a taste some wines. It's definitely a good time on your way to or from the Navigli district.

spots.label: Duomo di Milano
spots.notes:
No first trip to Milan is complete without a trip to the Duomo. It's massive and unavoidable. If I remember correctly, it's the 5th largest cathedral in the world. If you're lucky, someone will be playing the organ when you visit the inside.

For a great view of the city, be sure to visit the roof.

spots.label: San Lorenzo Maggiore
spots.notes: The church right near the columns of Porta Ticinese – worth a visit if you are near it. It's clean and beautiful and there's a nice park area behind it where you can have a rest or just enjoy the weather if it's good.

spots.label: Cantina della Vetra
spots.notes:
We had a lovely lunch here with a good salami plate, some wonderful burrata and some stuffed pasta (with zucca) that were really good. The bottle of Franciacorta wine wasn't bad either. I'd definitely go again.

Here's where I learned by watching some locals how to spread risotto around a plate so it cools faster.

spots.label: Basillica di Sant'Ambrogio
spots.notes: A beautiful church worth a trip inside to see it.

spots.label: San Marco Market
spots.notes: Monday and Thursday mornings a great market happens here with a mixture of food, clothing and household items. I went for the food (big surprise). Despite being in/near the fancy Brera neighborhood prices were good. A whole roasted chicken was 5.50€ and i bought 4 blocks of good cheese (pecorino, parmeggiano, talegio, brigante) for just 12€. (Note: those are 2009 prices. For comparison, the same chicken in Paris in 2013 was at least 10€.)
